elements.text: [Part One]
No, I don't always win.
Internal door opens and closes.
Evelyn, how are you?
I've been thinking, Doctor.
Yes, so have I, and I have an excellent idea. Here.
Moves chair.
No, thank you. I'll stand.
Not on ceremony, I hope.
Don't make light of this, Doctor.
I'm sorry, truly, I'm really not trying to.
I've spent the last few hours just thinking about things. About Cassie, and what happened to her. And about your manner.
I can't change what happened. I never can. True, I may, in the past, have found myself the catalyst for events, but I cannot just go back and change what's already happened just to suit myself.
I know that, Doctor. I'm not a fool.
No, I'm sorry, of course you're not.
But I still need time to think things through. You've had more experience at this kind of thing. I can't just switch the emotions on and off between battles for the universe.
Is that what you think I do, Evelyn?
I'm sorry, Doctor, I just thought
Do you want some time on your own, some time apart? Is that it?
I'm not sure.
Do you want to leave me?
I didn't think so. I don't know

I'd hate to think that there could be anything irreconcilable between us. Listen, there's a place I've frequented oft before when the need has come to relax. The Eye of Orion. We can walk. You can walk. Alone. It's not unlike the English South Downs. Not so many sheep.
No, Doctor. I don't want to just relax. I want to do things with the time that I've got left.
The time that you've got left?
None of us is getting any younger, are we?
Oh, of course. Of course.
I want to be somewhere where we don't have to get involved. At least, not in an exhausting way. I need time to think.
Well, we'll be involved just by being anywhere. As my old friend Schr√©dinger used to say, the act of observation itself can change the observed act.

Oh Doctor, I've had enough of this avoidance and pedantry. Perhaps I do want some time alone. Yes. Find me an interesting period, somewhere, anywhere. Somewhere where you don't have to help the underdog or rally the resistance. Somewhere I can just be, and talk to people, to learn.
An admirable sentiment. Yes, I'll find you somewhere. How long would you like to stay?
I don't know. I'll be in my room.
Wood moving against wood, then music.
When she was young, she slept all day. She'd only wake to eat or play. When she was older she slept till noon.
Knock on door.
With half the time for game or tune.
Door opens.
And now she rises with the sun.
Door closes.
Time filled with work. No time for fun.
Closes music box.
Governor Rossiter.
Princess Krisztina. I apologise for startling you, but er
But it is time to attend the announcement.
Yes, Princess. That particular verse was a favourite of my daughter's when she was a little girl.
She told me.
It always made her cry, but she would always have me sing it again.
It is about the end of childhood, about growing up and facing one's duty and responsibilities. Will I have the honour of your escort, Governor?

I'm afraid not, Princess. I must introduce the proceedings. I believe a Trooper has been stationed by the lift to escort you down. He will also attend you in the carriage during the procession through the city. I believe there are a million of your subjects outside the Palace alone.
She starts the music box again.
Tell me, do you think it would still make Sophia cry?
Her father's too old now to carry the tune, I fear.
Nevertheless, I'm sure she would still like to hear it. I shall finish dressing, Governor. Please make your introductions in your own time.
Your Highness.
Distant cheering crowd.
I suggest, Mortund, we get this farce over with. When does Rossiter intend to begin?
Plenipotentiary Suskind, I'm afraid I have to protest once again at your attitude.
My attitude. Protest all you like, but I still, I think, have autonomy left to possess my own opinions.
Then if not of your attitude, of its public display.
We may not see eye to eye politically, Paramount Minister, but I'd have thought even Rossiter would agree this is nothing more than glitz for the cameras.

The cameras are here for our benefit, not we for theirs. We've been over and over this in committee for years, Suskind. It's been decided. It is the only course left to us. What would you prefer? Does it suit you to have our countries warring?
There is at least a dignity in war. This is nothing but showmanship. Does anyone really think this, this sham of a marriage, a paper-thin bond, will unite us?
Your opposition has been noted. But I tell you again that its public expression serves only to fuel the demonstrations, both here in Galen and Melendia too.
The demonstrations only go to prove my opinions to be correct. No one, either in Galen or in Melendia, will recognise this union. This fawning crowd is representative of no one.
Yours is a lone voice, Suskind. Your own Melendian cabinet voted against you.
Gentlemen, I think they're ready for us.
Thank you, Governor Rossiter. A marriage between the Prince and Princess will go ahead, Plenipotentiary. Our kingdoms will be allied. The fighting will stop.
Leaves.
Your kingdom alliance will not outlast the day, Paramount Minister.
Beeps, door opens. A voice speaks through a faceplate, making it sound slightly mechanical.
Your Highness.
City level selected.
Loud cheers. Tapping on microphone.

Subjects of Galen. As Governor of the Republic of Kozapen, I know only too well that my people share a border with both yourselves and the people of Melendia. For centuries my predecessors have watched your two great kingdoms locked needlessly in violent and tragic disagreement. Disagreement that has seen land and lives lost on either side. But from today all that will truly become something for the history books.
Cheers.
Trooper.
Yes, Your Highness.
What do you think of all this? The alliance, the end of the war, the arranged marriage?
I think, Your Highness, it is not my place to think.
I didn't mean to offend you, Trooper. I simply wanted your opinion as a fighting man. Have you been posted along the border?
Yes.
Then you've seen people die.
Yes, Princess. I've also made them die.
Lift stops.
Descent arrested.
Then tell me how you feel about this kingdom alliance. How will it affect you?
How will your marriage affect me? Can I ask you something before I answer?
Of course.
Is it true what some of the news media have been saying, that you do not love Prince Viktor. That the Prince himself has sacrificed his own relationship to marry you.
It's no secret in Galen or in any other country. The wedding is a symbol. Our marriage will be a political expediency. Our children will be an insurance policy.
Then you don't want to marry the Prince.

What I want, Trooper, and what I have the opportunity to do for my country, are entirely different things. This marriage will save lives. Or at least, I suppose it will. I asked you for your opinion on that matter, and you haven't given it to me. Well? Is this a charade or am I preventing thousands of deaths?
I think you should not marry a man you don't love.
It's hardly as simple as that, Trooper.
Yeah, well, you always did overcomplicate things.
What did you say?
I think we should continue, Princess Krisztina. The Governor will be announcing you soon.
You seem to have lost the name patch from your uniform.
Sometimes we remove them, Your Highness. Superstition.
But you can tell me your name, can't you, Trooper.
We should leave, Princess.
Descent re-engaged.
It is my duty to take you to the procession at the allotted time.
Descent arrested.
Tell me your name.
You're not helping, Princess.
Is that your only duty, Trooper, to take me to the procession?
Your Highness.
Isn't it your duty to stay with me throughout the procession?
Princess.
Why won't you tell me your name? Isn't it your duty to stand between me and those demonstrators who believe I am betraying my country? Isn't it your duty to stand between me and a bullet?
Krisztina. I will defend your life with my own. But not because it's my duty. (removes helmet) It's my wish.
Marcus! You (slap!)

So it has fallen to me, as independent arbitrator of the talks for the cessation of war, to formally announce to your two great kingdoms, and indeed to all the nations of Vilag, the means by which peace will be brought to us this day.
Cheers almost drowning him out.

I refer, of course. I refer, of course to the marriage between Krisztina, Princess of Galen, and Viktor, Prince and heir to the throne of Melendia. This marriage officially marks, officially marks the birth of the Kingdom Alliance, uniting your people in politics as in blood
Multiple explosions.
Krisztina.
I'm okay.
Let me see. Apart for five years, and after five minutes back together, the entire world seems to want us dead.
You're going to wish you were dead if we ever get out of this alive.
Now, Morten, will you believe that your pathetic union is not wanted?
You surprise me by still being here, Plenipotentiary. I'm certain the rats left some time ago.
Princess! Princess! Krisztina!
Knock on door.
[OC]: Evelyn? I've found somewhere. We're on the way.
Oh, for goodness sake come in, Doctor. You make me feel like a child that refuses to come down for tea.
Ah. Walking boots after all. They're very nice.
So where am I going?
Ah yes, going. The planet Vilag. No underdogs, no need of intervention. Doctor's honour.
Will I look out of place?
No, shouldn't think so.
Anything I need to know?
Ah, yes. May I?
Be my guest.

Ah, well, er, now. Vilag. It has a single landmass, which at present is divided between three countries. The two largest, Galen and Melendia, are monarchies. The actual legislative power of both sovereignties has relatively recently passed into symbolism, but the families themselves are still revered and looked to as role models if not policy makers.
Makes a change from footballers and half-naked twelve year old pop stars.

Indeed. I thought we'd land in Galen, a little after the announcement of the Kingdom Alliance, the union of these two, well, superpowers, for the want of a fresher term. They've been at war for a century or so, but the proverbial bird of peace has just landed upon their shores.
And we won't need to take this bird of peace under our own wing.

Exactly. Oh, there will have been some violent anti-alliance demonstrations in both countries, of course, but the worst of these, an attack on the Galen palace itself, happened oh er more than a week ago, relative to our arrival.
Anywhere on the continent I should avoid in the immediate future?
Where were you thinking of going?
I wasn't thinking of going anywhere. I just might end up somewhere.

Oh, quite. Well, actually, that's the really interesting bit. In about a month, a race called the Killorans will invade the planet quite unexpectedly. Nasty lot. Run into them once or twice before. Humanoid with canine overtones, all angry and bestial.
I don't think I'll learn much in the middle of an invasion, Doctor.

Oh no, no, no, no, we'll leave long before then. With the formation of the Alliance, Galen and Melendia will have stopped fighting each other and stand together to sling-shot the Killorans straight back out into space. Nothing for us to do at all. I thought we could just experience the eventual coming together in peace of two old family houses. We'll have a good five or six weeks before the fireworks start.
And just what is it that's made these two monarchies stop trying to poke each other's eyes out?
Oh, something and nothing, I expect. Something about an arranged marriage, I think. Well, that's not the point. All we have to do is turn up and wander around. Well, what do you say?
Aren't you coming to see me off?
Wait. Evelyn. Don't leave like this.
The Tardis materialises by a fountain. Door opens.
Mmm, thank you, Doctor. This seems just the ticket.
(approaching) Evelyn, wait. Oh, botanic gardens, I assume. Perhaps I should leave my coat. Evelyn, have you seen all this wonderful flora? The flowers, they're making, well, sounds like
music as you pass them. That's unique, I expect. Probably. Evelyn? Wait a minute.
I need some time away from you, Doctor.

Evelyn, wait for me. Oh, what can I do, Doctor Smythe? What can I do? We're close to the palace. The gardens are open to the public. You shouldn't have any trouble. I'll just amuse myself then, shall I?
Sounds of hammering.
Governor Rossiter, how are your injuries?
Injuries be damned, Mortund. Look to your own. I've come to see Krisztina, again. Am I to be permitted this time?
The Princess is recovering well, Governor, and Galen thanks you for your country's concern.
I'm not here as a representative of my country, man. How is the girl?
She's currently unavailable.
Oh, for pity's sake, Mortund. I've just come to see if Krisztina's okay, one friend to another.
Of course. It seems she's decided to take a turn round the gardens. The maid assumes she wished to supervise the clean-up operations.
Is she alone?
There's no cause for alarm. All the demonstrators were apprehended, as you know, and security arrangements are in place.
Oh, I'll find the poor girl myself.
(breathless) Oh, stupid, stupid old woman, racing off like that just to prove a point. And in this heat. Ah! Oh! Start acting your age. Now, ah!
(echoing) Hello? Hello? Are you all right? Can I help you? Can you hear me? Can you hear me?

(quoting Tennyson) Yet pull not down my palace towers that are so lightly, beautifully built. Perchance I may return with others there when I have purged my guilt. Hmm. I suppose I could find my own Tower of Art and sit in contemplation. Perhaps that would put the smile back on Doctor Smythe's face. Or, why contemplate in a tower, when one can do it whist fishing?
By running water, pebbles are splashing into it.
Oh, fool. You'll scare away all the, well, whatever comprises the dominant indigent piscean species. Hey, young man. Would you cease doing that? You're scaring the fist.
What?
Oh, military man, I see.
Off duty.
And you thought you'd come down here to do a spot of stone-skimming, eh?
Hmm?
Your name, perhaps?
Reid. Corporal, 125727.
Pleased to meet you. I'm the Doctor and this, oh no. So, 125727, I thought you were off duty.
What? Oh yes, sorry, Doctor. Marcus Reid.
Well, Marcus Reid, do you know how many millions of years it took for those stones to reach land? And you've just chucked them back in. You're a geologist's nightmare.
Evelyn wakes.
It's okay. You're all right. If you can stand, I think we should move you over into the shade. You were too close to the flowers. They can be quite intoxicating at this time of year.
Flowers? I felt disorientated.
I'm sorry, are you a tourist? The Zenablossoms. When a strong enough wind blows across them, it causes vibrations and harmonics. It can even be hypnotising to old
To old people.
That was tactless of me.
Not at all, my dear. Can you see my handbag? Plenty of things are reminding me of my age these days. Why shouldn't you make one more?
Here. Are you ill?
Thank you. Er, not so that I care to think about it at the moment. Now, my name is Evelyn Smythe. Thank you very much indeed, young lady, for helping me.
You're very welcome.
And you are?
I'm terribly sorry, that was so rude. I'm afraid I assumed you recognised me. My name's Krisztina Prain.
Well, Krisztina, I'm happy to have met you. May I ask why I should have recognised you? Should I have seen your latest movie, perhaps?
I'm not a celebrity, if that's what you mean. I'm the Princess of Galen.

Gosh. Then it's I who must apologise. I've been moving around rather a lot lately. Not staying put in one place for any decent length of time can make one seem rather ignorant in certain circumstances.
Princess, I thought I saw you. Oh, my goodness, madam. Are you all right? Can I be of assistance?
Princess Krisztina has been looking after me wonderfully. But thank you.
Just Krisztina, please. Evelyn, this is Governor Rossiter.
Charmed to make your acquaintance, madam. I like your boots.
Thank you. The pleasure's all mine, I'm sure.

Governor, I find suddenly I am late for an appointment. I wonder if you would escort Evelyn back to the Palace for me. Evelyn, I hope I'll get back before you have to leave. I would very much like us to get to know one another better.
I should like that too, Krisztina.
Princess, I know who you appointment is with.
You do?

You used to write to Sophia about him, years ago, before he left for the Army. You told her all about Marcus Reid. When I told her the name of the Trooper who'd rescued you from the lift, well, she tried to hide it, but I'm afraid I made her tell me everything.
Whatever your daughter may remember from our childhood correspondence, Governor, I assure you, you do not know everything.
Krisztina, I know that you still love this man, but you cannot, for the sake of your country

Don't presume to lecture me on my duty, Governor. And to complete your knowledge about my affairs, I shall tell you that yes, I am now going to meet Marcus, but it is only with the intention of telling him that we can never see each other again. I know where my responsibilities lie, Governor. I would expect this kind of treatment from Plenipotentiary Suskind, not from you. (leaves.)
Oh dear.
I seem to have been rather a fool.
Hmm. Come on, you'd better take me to the Palace.
Alarms.
You know, I'm not sure, but I think the idea is to open the hatch.
Well, it's reassuring to know that your sense of humour has remained as sophisticated as it ever was.
Let me blast the bloody thing.
And risk cutting the cable and sending us crashing to our deaths? I'd like to die in your arms, sweetheart, but I wasn't figuring on doing it for another seventy years or so.
Did we get married and no one told me?
Hatch finally battered open.
Right, can you pull yourself through?
(effort) I can, but how will you get up?
Don't worry about me. What can you see?
It's dark, but there's a crack of light.
Gunshots in distance.
The cable's cut half through and frayed. It's unravelling itself. We're just under one of the floors. I can reach up to the bottom of the lip of the doors easily, but I don't know if
Krista!
I'm okay. It was just the hatch. I think I can prise the doors apart.
Here.
Big efforts, grating metal, alarms now louder.
You first.
Give me your hand.
Behind you, two of them. Get down!
Shots, gurgles.
Marcus, get out of there!
My gun!
Forget it. Give me your hand.
More effort.
Thanks.
[OC]: Krisztina!
I need to see you again.
When?
I'll wait for you every evening on our bridge. Remember?
Of course I remember.
Thank the heavens you're alive. You're face, you're bleeding.
I'll be okay, Governor.
What's your name, Trooper?
Reid, Corporal, 125727, sir.
Damn fine job, Reid. Now let's get the hell out of here.
And so you rescued this young lady, an old flame, no less, from the besieged Palace, and now want to live happily ever after. Three, four, five. Ah ha! My lead, I believe.
They are competing at skimming stones.
What's to stop you? You seem like a healthy enough chap to me.
It's not that simple. I haven't told you the whole story.
Nonsense. Oh, I expect your parents don't like her, or she comes from the wrong kind of family, or some such.
Well, it is to do with her family.

Arrant nonsense. Listen, Marcus. A friend and I were just quarrelling about. Well, anyway, my point is that we all have choices, and no matter how much we may want to we can never go back and undo the actions we've taken.
So you have to be sure to always do the right thing.

Well, no, that's not what I mean. Oh, bad luck. Rather, you have to be happy with what you do do. Or maybe not happy. Comfortable. No, one has to be able to live with the consequences of one's actions.
And your friend can't live with his?
Hers. It's more the fact she can't live with mine. No, that's not it, exactly.
She's not okay with the way you can. Live with them, I mean. The consequences of your actions.
Yeah, that would seem to be the case.
But the consequences of my actions could be so devastating.
Which consequences can you live with? Those of doing nothing, or those of doing anything to be with the woman you are so obviously devoted to.
But the cost.
Oh, hang the cost. What you have to ask yourself is, are you the kind of person who can live with a decision that turns out to have devastating consequences?
Like you.
It's not as clear-cut as that.

Doctor, you're right. All I wanted to do was see her one last time, to say goodbye properly this time. But you're right. If our love leads to war, then we have to accept those consequences. We may lose friendships, as you say you have done, but we will be together.
Lead to war? I shouldn't think it would quite come to that.
But it could. Krista is Princess Krisztina of Galen.
What?
It's been arranged for her to marry the Prince of Melendia. The whole Kingdom Alliance hangs on the ceremony.
The arranged marriage?
Marcus?
Krista.
Oh, er
I love you.
I know, but
But nothing. I walked away from you once. I won't do it again.
We can't. We can't be together. Can we?
We can do anything.

Oh Doctor, what have you done? If they're found out, then the arranged marriage will be called off, the Alliance will break up, the war will start again, and when the Killorans arrive they'll tear this planet apart. And it'll all be my fault!

KRISZTINA: Isn't it your duty to stay with me throughout the procession?
REID: Princess.
KRISZTINA: Why won't you tell me your name? Isn't it your duty to stand between me and those demonstrators who believe I am betraying my country? Isn't it your duty to stand between me and a bullet?
REID: Krisztina. I will defend your life with my own. But not because it's my duty. (removes helmet) It's my wish.
KRISZTINA: Marcus! You (slap!)
ROSSITER: So it has fallen to me, as independent arbitrator of the talks for the cessation of war, to formally announce to your two great kingdoms, and indeed to all the nations of Vilag, the means by which peace will be brought to us this day.
ROSSITER: I refer, of course. I refer, of course to the marriage between Krisztina, Princess of Galen, and Viktor, Prince and heir to the throne of Melendia. This marriage officially marks, officially marks the birth of the Kingdom Alliance, uniting your people in politics as in blood
REID: Krisztina.
KRISZTINA: I'm okay.
REID: Let me see. Apart for five years, and after five minutes back together, the entire world seems to want us dead.
KRISZTINA: You're going to wish you were dead if we ever get out of this alive.
SUSKIND: Now, Morten, will you believe that your pathetic union is not wanted?
MORTEN: You surprise me by still being here, Plenipotentiary. I'm certain the rats left some time ago.
ROSSITER: Princess! Princess! Krisztina!
DOCTOR: [OC]: Evelyn? I've found somewhere. We're on the way.
EVELYN: Oh, for goodness sake come in, Doctor. You make me feel like a child that refuses to come down for tea.
DOCTOR: Ah. Walking boots after all. They're very nice.
EVELYN: So where am I going?
DOCTOR: Ah yes, going. The planet Vilag. No underdogs, no need of intervention. Doctor's honour.
EVELYN: Will I look out of place?
DOCTOR: No, shouldn't think so.
EVELYN: Anything I need to know?
DOCTOR: Ah, yes. May I?
EVELYN: Be my guest.
DOCTOR: Ah, well, er, now. Vilag. It has a single landmass, which at present is divided between three countries. The two largest, Galen and Melendia, are monarchies. The actual legislative power of both sovereignties has relatively recently passed into symbolism, but the families themselves are still revered and looked to as role models if not policy makers.
EVELYN: Makes a change from footballers and half-naked twelve year old pop stars.
DOCTOR: Indeed. I thought we'd land in Galen, a little after the announcement of the Kingdom Alliance, the union of these two, well, superpowers, for the want of a fresher term. They've been at war for a century or so, but the proverbial bird of peace has just landed upon their shores.
EVELYN: And we won't need to take this bird of peace under our own wing.
DOCTOR: Exactly. Oh, there will have been some violent anti-alliance demonstrations in both countries, of course, but the worst of these, an attack on the Galen palace itself, happened oh er more than a week ago, relative to our arrival.
EVELYN: Anywhere on the continent I should avoid in the immediate future?
DOCTOR: Where were you thinking of going?
EVELYN: I wasn't thinking of going anywhere. I just might end up somewhere.
DOCTOR: Oh, quite. Well, actually, that's the really interesting bit. In about a month, a race called the Killorans will invade the planet quite unexpectedly. Nasty lot. Run into them once or twice before. Humanoid with canine overtones, all angry and bestial.
EVELYN: I don't think I'll learn much in the middle of an invasion, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Oh no, no, no, no, we'll leave long before then. With the formation of the Alliance, Galen and Melendia will have stopped fighting each other and stand together to sling-shot the Killorans straight back out into space. Nothing for us to do at all. I thought we could just experience the eventual coming together in peace of two old family houses. We'll have a good five or six weeks before the fireworks start.
EVELYN: And just what is it that's made these two monarchies stop trying to poke each other's eyes out?
DOCTOR: Oh, something and nothing, I expect. Something about an arranged marriage, I think. Well, that's not the point. All we have to do is turn up and wander around. Well, what do you say?
EVELYN: Aren't you coming to see me off?
DOCTOR: Wait. Evelyn. Don't leave like this.
EVELYN: Mmm, thank you, Doctor. This seems just the ticket.
DOCTOR: (approaching) Evelyn, wait. Oh, botanic gardens, I assume. Perhaps I should leave my coat. Evelyn, have you seen all this wonderful flora? The flowers, they're making, well, sounds like
EVELYN: I need some time away from you, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Evelyn, wait for me. Oh, what can I do, Doctor Smythe? What can I do? We're close to the palace. The gardens are open to the public. You shouldn't have any trouble. I'll just amuse myself then, shall I?
MORTUND: Governor Rossiter, how are your injuries?
ROSSITER: Injuries be damned, Mortund. Look to your own. I've come to see Krisztina, again. Am I to be permitted this time?
MORTUND: The Princess is recovering well, Governor, and Galen thanks you for your country's concern.
ROSSITER: I'm not here as a representative of my country, man. How is the girl?
MORTUND: She's currently unavailable.
ROSSITER: Oh, for pity's sake, Mortund. I've just come to see if Krisztina's okay, one friend to another.
MORTUND: Of course. It seems she's decided to take a turn round the gardens. The maid assumes she wished to supervise the clean-up operations.
ROSSITER: Is she alone?
MORTUND: There's no cause for alarm. All the demonstrators were apprehended, as you know, and security arrangements are in place.
ROSSITER: Oh, I'll find the poor girl myself.
EVELYN: (breathless) Oh, stupid, stupid old woman, racing off like that just to prove a point. And in this heat. Ah! Oh! Start acting your age. Now, ah!
KRISZTINA: (echoing) Hello? Hello? Are you all right? Can I help you? Can you hear me? Can you hear me?
DOCTOR: (quoting Tennyson) Yet pull not down my palace towers that are so lightly, beautifully built. Perchance I may return with others there when I have purged my guilt. Hmm. I suppose I could find my own Tower of Art and sit in contemplation. Perhaps that would put the smile back on Doctor Smythe's face. Or, why contemplate in a tower, when one can do it whist fishing?
DOCTOR: Oh, fool. You'll scare away all the, well, whatever comprises the dominant indigent piscean species. Hey, young man. Would you cease doing that? You're scaring the fist.
REID: What?
DOCTOR: Oh, military man, I see.
REID: Off duty.
DOCTOR: And you thought you'd come down here to do a spot of stone-skimming, eh?
REID: Hmm?
DOCTOR: Your name, perhaps?
REID: Reid. Corporal, 125727.
DOCTOR: Pleased to meet you. I'm the Doctor and this, oh no. So, 125727, I thought you were off duty.
REID: What? Oh yes, sorry, Doctor. Marcus Reid.
DOCTOR: Well, Marcus Reid, do you know how many millions of years it took for those stones to reach land? And you've just chucked them back in. You're a geologist's nightmare.
KRISZTINA: It's okay. You're all right. If you can stand, I think we should move you over into the shade. You were too close to the flowers. They can be quite intoxicating at this time of year.
EVELYN: Flowers? I felt disorientated.
KRISZTINA: I'm sorry, are you a tourist? The Zenablossoms. When a strong enough wind blows across them, it causes vibrations and harmonics. It can even be hypnotising to old
EVELYN: To old people.
KRISZTINA: That was tactless of me.
EVELYN: Not at all, my dear. Can you see my handbag? Plenty of things are reminding me of my age these days. Why shouldn't you make one more?
KRISZTINA: Here. Are you ill?
EVELYN: Thank you. Er, not so that I care to think about it at the moment. Now, my name is Evelyn Smythe. Thank you very much indeed, young lady, for helping me.
KRISZTINA: You're very welcome.
EVELYN: And you are?
KRISZTINA: I'm terribly sorry, that was so rude. I'm afraid I assumed you recognised me. My name's Krisztina Prain.
EVELYN: Well, Krisztina, I'm happy to have met you. May I ask why I should have recognised you? Should I have seen your latest movie, perhaps?
KRISZTINA: I'm not a celebrity, if that's what you mean. I'm the Princess of Galen.
EVELYN: Gosh. Then it's I who must apologise. I've been moving around rather a lot lately. Not staying put in one place for any decent length of time can make one seem rather ignorant in certain circumstances.
ROSSITER: Princess, I thought I saw you. Oh, my goodness, madam. Are you all right? Can I be of assistance?
EVELYN: Princess Krisztina has been looking after me wonderfully. But thank you.
KRISZTINA: Just Krisztina, please. Evelyn, this is Governor Rossiter.
ROSSITER: Charmed to make your acquaintance, madam. I like your boots.
EVELYN: Thank you. The pleasure's all mine, I'm sure.
KRISZTINA: Governor, I find suddenly I am late for an appointment. I wonder if you would escort Evelyn back to the Palace for me. Evelyn, I hope I'll get back before you have to leave. I would very much like us to get to know one another better.
EVELYN: I should like that too, Krisztina.
ROSSITER: Princess, I know who you appointment is with.
KRISZTINA: You do?
ROSSITER: You used to write to Sophia about him, years ago, before he left for the Army. You told her all about Marcus Reid. When I told her the name of the Trooper who'd rescued you from the lift, well, she tried to hide it, but I'm afraid I made her tell me everything.
KRISZTINA: Whatever your daughter may remember from our childhood correspondence, Governor, I assure you, you do not know everything.
ROSSITER: Krisztina, I know that you still love this man, but you cannot, for the sake of your country
KRISZTINA: Don't presume to lecture me on my duty, Governor. And to complete your knowledge about my affairs, I shall tell you that yes, I am now going to meet Marcus, but it is only with the intention of telling him that we can never see each other again. I know where my responsibilities lie, Governor. I would expect this kind of treatment from Plenipotentiary Suskind, not from you. (leaves.)
EVELYN: Oh dear.
ROSSITER: I seem to have been rather a fool.
EVELYN: Hmm. Come on, you'd better take me to the Palace.
REID: You know, I'm not sure, but I think the idea is to open the hatch.
KRISZTINA: Well, it's reassuring to know that your sense of humour has remained as sophisticated as it ever was.
REID: Let me blast the bloody thing.
KRISZTINA: And risk cutting the cable and sending us crashing to our deaths? I'd like to die in your arms, sweetheart, but I wasn't figuring on doing it for another seventy years or so.
REID: Did we get married and no one told me?
REID: Right, can you pull yourself through?
KRISZTINA: (effort) I can, but how will you get up?
REID: Don't worry about me. What can you see?
KRISZTINA: It's dark, but there's a crack of light.
KRISZTINA: The cable's cut half through and frayed. It's unravelling itself. We're just under one of the floors. I can reach up to the bottom of the lip of the doors easily, but I don't know if
REID: Krista!
KRISZTINA: I'm okay. It was just the hatch. I think I can prise the doors apart.
REID: Here.
REID: You first.
KRISZTINA: Give me your hand.
REID: Behind you, two of them. Get down!
KRISZTINA: Marcus, get out of there!
REID: My gun!
KRISZTINA: Forget it. Give me your hand.
REID: Thanks.
ROSSITER: [OC]: Krisztina!
REID: I need to see you again.
KRISZTINA: When?
REID: I'll wait for you every evening on our bridge. Remember?
KRISZTINA: Of course I remember.
ROSSITER: Thank the heavens you're alive. You're face, you're bleeding.
KRISZTINA: I'll be okay, Governor.
ROSSITER: What's your name, Trooper?
REID: Reid, Corporal, 125727, sir.
ROSSITER: Damn fine job, Reid. Now let's get the hell out of here.
DOCTOR: And so you rescued this young lady, an old flame, no less, from the besieged Palace, and now want to live happily ever after. Three, four, five. Ah ha! My lead, I believe.
DOCTOR: What's to stop you? You seem like a healthy enough chap to me.
REID: It's not that simple. I haven't told you the whole story.
DOCTOR: Nonsense. Oh, I expect your parents don't like her, or she comes from the wrong kind of family, or some such.
REID: Well, it is to do with her family.
DOCTOR: Arrant nonsense. Listen, Marcus. A friend and I were just quarrelling about. Well, anyway, my point is that we all have choices, and no matter how much we may want to we can never go back and undo the actions we've taken.
REID: So you have to be sure to always do the right thing.
DOCTOR: Well, no, that's not what I mean. Oh, bad luck. Rather, you have to be happy with what you do do. Or maybe not happy. Comfortable. No, one has to be able to live with the consequences of one's actions.
REID: And your friend can't live with his?
DOCTOR: Hers. It's more the fact she can't live with mine. No, that's not it, exactly.
REID: She's not okay with the way you can. Live with them, I mean. The consequences of your actions.
DOCTOR: Yeah, that would seem to be the case.
REID: But the consequences of my actions could be so devastating.
DOCTOR: Which consequences can you live with? Those of doing nothing, or those of doing anything to be with the woman you are so obviously devoted to.
REID: But the cost.
DOCTOR: Oh, hang the cost. What you have to ask yourself is, are you the kind of person who can live with a decision that turns out to have devastating consequences?
REID: Like you.
DOCTOR: It's not as clear-cut as that.
REID: Doctor, you're right. All I wanted to do was see her one last time, to say goodbye properly this time. But you're right. If our love leads to war, then we have to accept those consequences. We may lose friendships, as you say you have done, but we will be together.
DOCTOR: Lead to war? I shouldn't think it would quite come to that.
REID: But it could. Krista is Princess Krisztina of Galen.
DOCTOR: What?
REID: It's been arranged for her to marry the Prince of Melendia. The whole Kingdom Alliance hangs on the ceremony.
DOCTOR: The arranged marriage?
KRISZTINA: Marcus?
REID: Krista.
DOCTOR: Oh, er
REID: I love you.
KRISZTINA: I know, but
REID: But nothing. I walked away from you once. I won't do it again.
KRISZTINA: We can't. We can't be together. Can we?
REID: We can do anything.
DOCTOR: Oh Doctor, what have you done? If they're found out, then the arranged marriage will be called off, the Alliance will break up, the war will start again, and when the Killorans arrive they'll tear this planet apart. And it'll all be my fault!

elements.text: [Part Two]
Turning pages. Dialling on a telephone.
[OC]: Yes, Plenipotentiary Suskind, sir?
Ah, is this line secure your end, Commander Pokol?
[OC]: Yes, sir.
Good. Change of plan, Pokol. The idiot in charge of the Galen palace attack botched it, as
I'm sure you're aware. That irritating little bitch is still alive, and I nearly lost my head into the bargain.
[OC]: Disgraceful, sir. But things have pretty much gone as planned over here.
Yes. Congratulations on your own activities, Commander. I've been following the Melendian news. Eighteen dead, wasn't it?
[OC]: That's correct, sir. All phase one operations are now complete. Me and the boys will go to ground as arranged.
Actually, Commander, I want you and the boys here in Galen with me. I'll arrange a dozen visas. Your official status will be as my personal bodyguard, in light of recent events. Understood?
[OC]: Loud and clear, sir.
I want the balance of power in this wretched country shifted. Get here as soon as you can, Pokol.
[OC]: Sir.
But Krisztina, please listen.

No, Marcus. We can't do this. The last ten nights I've been lying awake just thinking about us. For the last ten evenings I've known that I could just walk down here and be with you. Things have changed. Our lives have changed. We're different people now.
Quite right.
Who are you?
Ah yes, pleased to meet you, Your Highness. I am known as the Doctor.
Are you indeed? I have to go.
You don't feel the same about me now as you did five years ago?
I'm not saying that. Excuse me, Doctor, but this is a private conversation.
Then you do.
I'm terribly sorry, but Marcus here has been telling me all about your woes
Whether I do or not is irrelevant. I have a duty to perform.
You have to prostitute yourself.
Slap!
How dare you!
Will you stop doing that?
I think that this is neither the time nor the place, hmm?
And just what business is it of yours?
It's okay, he's with me.
Oh, that's all right, then.
Princess, if I may, people are beginning to take notice of your contretemps, so I suggest we adjourn to somewhere a little more private, and continue this discussion there?
We can go to the thermal baths.
Yes. They've been closed to the public for years.
Then how do we get in?
We know a way.
Sir.
It's okay, Sergeant. Evelyn is a friend of the Princess, and I shall be escorting her into the Palace.
Very good, Governor Rossiter.
Walking slowly.
I must say, I do find myself a little out of character, so to speak, calling you simply by your given name.
Well, let me assure you that you have not only my permission, but my firm insistence. Were you to call me Doctor Smythe, I'd feel as though I were back in the staff room at Hallam.
Hallam?
Oh, a University, a long, long way from here.
You're not a Doctor of Medicine?
No, history.
Oh, good. I do so hate physicians. And you teach. I've often thought that a university campus must be such a stimulating environment.
It is. But I'm finding travelling so much more so.
And do you miss it? The teaching, I mean.
Well, I think I've just about come to the end on my tenure. I miss the students, and the communication of ideas. I don't miss the politics.
Ah.
Sorry, I should say campus politics, which is certainly far removed from actual politics. And indeed from politicians.
That's quite all right, I quite understand.

The Palace is amazing. The ramparts and towers, it must be a hundred storeys high. It's quite a view from here. Oh, is that the Botanic Gardens? I really do apologise. I wasn't trying to take a cheap shot at politicians. That's such a crass thing to do and should firmly remain the purview of under-informed undergraduates. I really take quite an amateur interest in the subject.
Have you ever considered standing for a local office?
No. I suspect I'm too idealistic for that. I would be one of those crushed by the wheels of others ambition.
Well, perhaps you should reconsider. May I say that with your sincerity added to what little I Know of your background, you've deprived us of a minor talent.
Flatterer. So if you're to call me Evelyn, I surely can't keep referring to you as Governor Rossiter.
Ah, well, er, there we hit something of a snag, I'm afraid.
Oh?
Even my late wife called me Rossiter, right up to the end.
Oh yes?
Oh, yes. My mother, you see, was in many ways something of a cruel woman.
Walking through water.
Look, I take it that this really is necessary? Only my socks are getting very soggy.
No one can see us here. The banks are too overgrown. And the stream flows through the baths, there.
Oh, and the old grille blocking the entrance?
Has a loose bar.
Which I loosened. We used to come here a lot.
Echoing.
Hardly appropriate information, Marcus.
I remember this place.
I haven't been down here since you left.
I should hope not.
Oh, I'm supposed to have stayed faithful to you, was I, after you disappeared?
I did.
Get out of the water. Not so much echo.
It's even more beautiful than I remember it. That ceiling.
Urgh. Oh, this is all my fault.
What is?
Well, I do rather feel that it was my somewhat ill-advised comments that have led us here.
But it's not your responsibility. It's ours.
Perhaps, perhaps. But I feel my role has been one of instigator, and for that I am responsible.
He's right in a way. I've been thinking for the last ten days too. I know you're right. I know you've got a duty to your country. You have to marry this Vincent guy.
Viktor. And he is the Prince of Melendia.

Right, whatever. What I'm saying is that I agreed with you. In fact, before the Doc here came along, I was trying to think of ways to let you down gently, so that you wouldn't feel too devastated about having lost me for a second time.
Oh, you were, were you?
But then the Doctor said something important.
Oh, I doubt it was really of any consequence. You should probably just forget all about it.

No, Doc, give yourself some credit. He said that the consequences we make, or the meaning of living with, deciding, well, I forget what it was he said exactly, but it made some damn sense to me then. Krista, you're more than just your duty.
Marcus.
Do you love me?
Of course I love you. I've always loved you. I loved you five years ago.
And five years ago I thought the way you're thinking now. Gardener's son in love with the Princess of the whole damn country. Stupid. It'll never happen. We said we loved each other, sure,
but it was never going to happen.
So you just ran away and joined the Army.
Something would have stopped us being together.
Something like this.
Yes. But now I know that none of that matters. It's the whole consequences thing.
You have to be willing to live with the consequences of your action or inaction.
Right. What he said. Thank you.
Don't mention it.
We can do it. We just have to have courage.
I have to marry Viktor.
And I won't try and stop you. I understand you have to do and I understand why. But just don't say that we can never see each other again. That's all I ask.
Do you really think we could
Look, perhaps there is a way. I have clearly had an influence on this young man's noble mind, and it's obvious that he's not going to give this up. I can help you.
How?
Well, the formation of the Kingdom Alliance is of paramount importance.
Of course.
Yet still you both want to be together?
Right. Krisztina, I've thought of nothing else but you every day of my life since I left. You're all I am.
Oh, Marcus, I've missed you so much.
Ahem. Well then, I suggest we make ourselves comfortable, because we have a lot to discuss.

It has now been almost a month since the devastating attack on the Galen Palace, and while actual military confrontation has ceased between Galen and Melendia, cynics would point out that isolated acts of terrorism in both capitals have increased in frequency. In Melendia too there have been signs of sporadic violence, some seemingly more organised than others. Two weeks ago, the Galen Ambassador to Melendia was among eighteen killed in an horrific drive-by shooting whilst addressing the public in the Melendian capital. Since that event, Paramount Minister Mortund of Galen has himself taken up the ambassadorial reins in Melendia, and has been keen to stress that the fundamental principles of the formation of the Kingdom Alliance have not been harmed.
These are not acts of deliberation by one organisation that wishes to see the failure of the Alliance. Such talk is wild, unhelpful, and unsubstantiated.
How long do you intend to stay in Melendia, Paramount Minister?
2: Will any other members of the Cabinet be joining you in Melendia.

Plenipotentiary Suskind, who remains in Galen, has made no further comment since his initial denunciation of the act, but perhaps the arrival a fortnight ago of what is apparently his armed personal body guard says enough about his opinion on the international political situation. Also still abroad is the newly appointed Special Envoy to Kozapen, Doctor Evelyn Smythe. She's been attending the latest round of consolidation talks, which ended earlier today.
I see my role as a purely advisory one. I'm not here to dictate policy. Please be careful where you're placing that microphone, young man.
Sorry, Doctor Smythe. Oh, nice boots, by the way.

Said to be extremely close to Princess Krisztina, Doctor Smythe there creating quite a stir. And so to news of the Princess, and a new appointment of her own. The addition to the Royal retinue of the man known only as the Doctor has been greeted with approval on nearly all sides. But is he more than just an astronomy tutor?
No, no, I don't have an official title. Tutor, advisor, PA. I just look upon myself as easing the burden of royal office in any small way I can.

And yes, these pictures coming to us live from Galen. The Princess and the Doctor arriving at the front of the 27th Infantry barracks, where the Princess will this afternoon be presenting Corporal Marcus Reid with an award for bravery. I'm sure you'll all remember it was Marcus who rescued Princess Krisztina during the unsuccessful attack on the Palace four weeks ago. I can't see Plenipotentiary Suskind, but my information is that he has already arrived.
Which is, after all, what war and conflict does.
Look at him down there, Pokol. He seems such a buffoon, doesn't he? And yet
I could still kill him, Plenipotentiary.

With his murder traceable directly to me, no doubt. No, Commander. Now that you and your unit are out in the open, I think we have no option other than to continue with the subtle approach. You'll have to take over the monitoring. Here. I have to make an appearance at this wretched exhibition of ersatz jingoism in the Quad.
I can't stand these things, sir. Never quite fit in your ear properly. So why are we bothering with the Doctor anyway?

Because the Princess is too well-protected, Pokol. And if you cannot attack your enemy, attack those closest to him. I want something that will politically embarrass him. We still no nothing about that ridiculous blue box of his.
It's just a shed, sir. He had it taken up to the Palace from the Botanic Gardens. I guess it's full of plants and stuff.
Never guess, Commander, with a man like the Doctor.
No, sir.
Stay here. I've got work to do.
Leaves.
Urgh. Uncomfortable damn thing.
That was wonderful.
You were wonderful.
Well, I must say, I wasn't expecting all that press attention afterwards. We hardly got out alive.
Your speech to the Council on the historical precedent was breathtaking.
Just common sense, really.
But when you spoke, it was like you were discovering it yourself for the first time. Such passion.
Well, I love this apartment. You can just run off the terrace and onto the sand.
Yours for as long as you want it. I'm glad Krisztina could talk you into coming back to Kozapen with me.
She seemed to think I could help her.
But the Doctor didn't come with you.
He has his own business to take care of.
Seems like a decent fellow. Have you known him long?
It's difficult to tell sometimes. What time's the video conference?
Oh, it's more than an hour away yet. What would you like to do in the meantime?
I thought I'd run through some notes, actually.
Excellent. We could work together, down on the beach.
You know, I think we've earned an hour on the beach. Notes be damned. Come on.
Both laughing.
Phone rings. Answerphone clicks in.
[OC]: This is Galen special envoy Doctor Evelyn Smythe. Oh, how grand am I. Please leave a message.

[OC]: Evelyn, it's the Doctor again. I wish you'd return just one of my calls. I just wanted to speak to you alone before the video conference later. Everything is going better than I could have hoped. I don't think we'll have any problems when the (ahem) you know who arrive in oh, three weeks or so. Krisztina and I have just arrived at the barracks for the ceremony. Perhaps you'll watch the broadcast? I wish I could talk to you, Evelyn. They're so happy now that they're together. I wish I could share it with you.
Sigh. Call ends.
Evelyn.
Doctor, there you are. I thought I'd lost you. Ah. Did you manage to speak with Evelyn?
I miss her.
I know.
They leave the room.
Perhaps if I talked to her?
Oh, thank you, Krista, but no. Doctor Smythe and I have things which can only be worked out between us. So then, today you will actually be seen with Marcus in public.
I still can't believe you managed to organise all this.
From the moment the ceremony ends, Marcus will officially be assigned to the Palace
Guard. We'll still need to be careful, but you'll at least be able to see each other every day, and I'll be able to pass messages between you with far greater ease than I have been.
Do you have my letters for him?
Safely tucked away in the homework you gave me this morning.
Through another door.
Can I ask
If I've forgiven him? Of course you can ask. You can read the letters if you like.

Goodness me no, no. I do know that he deeply regrets having left five years ago. But it was too much to cope with, Knowing that one day it would all fall apart. It would have to. And seeing you every day, holding you, falling into the lake when you took the boat out at midnight.
He told you about that?
Oh, my dear Krista, I suspect over the past weeks you have both (through another door) told me everything.
Come on. Brave the rain. That's the regimental anthem. I just saw Suskind come down the stairs, and Marcus'll already be out there on the podium.
Well then, we can't keep the hero waiting.
That's a nice button-hole. It's fresh, isn't it?
Indeed it is. How sweet of you to notice. Seems I share a love of flowers with one of the garden staff at the Palace. She gives me a new one every morning. This rose is rather becoming, I think.
Indeed it is.
You little
This is so undignified. Sitting under a bivouac in the freezing rain before a couple of thousand military cretins.

elements.text: [Part Three]
Here are the headlines.

[OC]: Letters indicating a wilful undermining of the political trust by Princess Krisztina of Galen. Minister Mortund has spent the last two days in exhaustive talks, trying to ensure the retention of the cease-fire between. Recent violent demonstrations have broken out between law enforcement and protesters

[OC]: Plenipotentiary of my country's government and speaker for the Crown. However, I hereby withdraw the arrangement of marriage previously consented by my office on behalf of Prince Viktor. Our countries are, regrettably, once again at war with one another.

[OC]: The Doctor, ex-Royal advisor, who is said to have been placed unofficial Palace arrest. The Doctor is apparently not allowed to leave the compound. Still raging after three days of renewed conflict. Passed the extradition order of Doctor Evelyn Smythe. Doctor Smythe four days ago appealed against the ruling. Marcus Reid, scandalised ex-lover of Galen's Princess Krisztina, is today heading to the front line. Minister Mortund is recovering in hospital today after a failed attempt on his life. The Doctor was apprehended trying to escape the Palace grounds and has now been placed under close arrest. Recent figures take the death toll on both sides above four hundred thousand in less than two weeks. Finally, after days of legal deliberation, Doctor Smythe's appeal has been denied, and she has been ordered to Kozapen within forty eight hours and return to Galen, where she will face conspiracy charges alongside the Doctor.
Sunset. Peace. Beauty. All just waiting to be destroyed. Oh, I feel so (knock on door) Come in. (door opens and closes) Rossiter!
Evelyn.
Is there any news from the Cabinet?

Doctor.
